column1: White-box testing	"White-box testing (also known as clear box testing
column4: and structural testing) is a method of software testing that tests internal structures or workings of an application
column5: as opposed to its functionality (i.e. black-box testing). In white-box testing
column6: an internal perspective of the system is used to design test cases. The tester chooses inputs to exercise paths through the code and determine the expected outputs. This is analogous to testing nodes in a circuit
column7: e.g. in-circuit testing (ICT). White-box testing can be applied at the unit
column8: integration and system levels of the software testing process. Although traditional testers tended to think of white-box testing as being done at the unit level
column9: it is used for integration and system testing more frequently today. It can test paths within a unit
column11: and between subsystems during a system¨Clevel test. Though this method of test design can uncover many errors or problems
column12: it has the potential to miss unimplemented parts of the specification or missing requirements. Where white-box testing is design-driven
column14: driven exclusively by agreed specifications of how each component of software is required to behave (as in DO-178C and ISO 26262 processes)
column15: white-box test techniques can accomplish assessment for unimplemented or missing requirements."

column1: Large Language Models as Simulated Economic Agents: What Can We Learn from Homo Silicus?	"Newly-developed large language models (LLM)¡ªbecause of how they are trained and designed¡ªare implicit computational models of humans¡ªa homo silicus. LLMs can be used like economists use homo economicus: they can be given endowments
column5: and then their behavior can be explored in scenarios via simulation. Experiments using this approach
column9: and Samuelson and Zeckhauser (1988) show qualitatively similar results to the original
column10: but it is also easy to try variations for fresh insights. LLMs could allow researchers to pilot studies via simulation first
column11: searching for novel social science insights to test in the real world."
